sect1.title: Working with Correlation DataCorrelation Data
sect1.para: Service calls often leave marks in multiple files: One file might records the call event, with a time stamp the user and the response time. The call itself may produce one or more messages in message files. The payload payload of the calls may be logged in some other files again. A service call by itself might trigger other service calls on other tierstiers of the solution.

In many cases it is, therefore, important to correlate log entriescorrelate log entries from various log files of different types. A common solution to this, is the usage of correlation idscorrelation ids, which allow the correlation of the log entries in different files.
&logtracker; offers support for correlating messages from any file, as long as a correlation id is extracted by an appropriate log parser configuration ().
An individual log entry is always starting point for an correlation analysiscorrelation analysis. An individual message can be selected via:

listitem.para: A service call dot within the service call scatter plot ().
An individual service call from the service call detail window ().
An individual log message from the message detail window ().

sect1.para: The correlation analysis is always invoked, by opening a context menucontext menu on the selected item (right-click with the mouse) and choosing Show correlated messages. A typical context menu is shown in . When this option is chosen, a correlated messages window pops up. Such a window is shown in . It lists all log entries with the same correlation id and sorts them by their occurrence time stamp. When the users selects an individual entry, its details are displays on the detail pane.

figure.title: A sample Correlated Messages WindowCorrelated Messages Window

sect1.para: &logtracker; also supports a Correlated Log FileCorrelated Log File log file type. This type is designed for log files that contain interesting data that can be correlated to other data by a correlation id but are not typical representatives of the other two types. They, for example, may lack service names, users, occurrence times, response times, etc. &logtracker; is not applying any specific evaluation to this type of files but it still gathers information from them and displays it when carrying out a correlation analysis.
A payload log could be a typical representative of this type of log file.
